main_text:
Syrianus (in antiquity known as “the Great”) was a teacher
of philosophy and, if we can trust the evidence, of rhetoric in Athens
during the late 4th and early 5th centuries CE.
He was a slightly younger contemporary of Augustine of Hippo
(354–430). Born in Alexandria in the second half of the
4th century, he received his basic education there but
later went on to study philosophy under Plutarch of Athens (c.
350–431/2), who had revived Plato’s Academy. When Plutarch
died in 431/2, Syrianus succeeded him as head of the Athenian school.
During this last stage in his life, Syrianus became the teacher of the
young Proclus (410/2–485), who in turn succeeded him as
scholarch, either immediately or not long after Syrianus’ death
in 437. The particular circumstances of Syrianus’ life are
almost entirely unknown, and of his copious philosophical work only
the important commentaries on books Beta (III),
Gamma (IV), and Mu and Nu (XIII–XIV)
of Aristotle’s Metaphysics survive.
